As a Canadian, these tariffs are not gonna go over very well. In the end, we will retaliate and it won’t cost the corporations or the politicians money. It will be working class people like me and you who will end up taking the brunt of this. It will skyrocket inflation. I support Trump completely but I don’t think he realizes or he’s taking into consideration that Canada is also the United States largest trading partner. We send so much of our steel and lumber and oil and gas and fuel and produce across the border. You are our number one consumer. Canada could be completely self-sufficient if we wanted to we don’t need to import anything, everything we need is right here, so this is just a really really bad move by Trump in my opinion. You’re targeting your closest ally and best friend in the world. We aren’t your enemy, we have fought and died beside each other in countless wars. We backed you up in Afghanistan and lost hundreds of our soldiers. When California was on fire, we sent our water bombers to come and help you. This isn’t the type of shit you do to your friend or ally. This is honestly sad to see this happening.

Less than two weeks into his term, President Donald Trump is waging war against his own government, creating a deep sense of fear in the federal workforce — and recipients of federal aid — as he tests the limits of his power to alter the scope, function and nonpartisan nature of government without Congress. 
Primarily using two little-known agencies — the Office of Management and Budget and the Office of Personnel Management — Trump has tried to choke off funding for a wide array of domestic and foreign assistance programs, made it easier to fire tens of thousands of federal workers, and launched a campaign to pressure more to resign from their posts.

President Trump’s announcement of a 25% tariff on imports from Mexico and Canada is the kind of policy that sounds tough, decisive—like it’s protecting American workers. But dig a little deeper, and the cracks in this approach become glaring. It’s the economic equivalent of setting fire to your neighbor’s house and then wondering why your own living room is getting smoky.
Tariffs are taxes, plain and simple. They don’t just land on foreign companies; they land on American consumers. That means when a shipment of tomatoes or avocados from Mexico arrives at the border, the cost jumps by 25% before it even hits grocery store shelves. Businesses aren’t going to eat that cost—they’ll pass it along to the consumer. And if you’re a working-class family already stretched thin, suddenly that simple bag of groceries is noticeably more expensive. The estimate that food costs will rise by 3% overall might sound small, but that’s an average across all food products. The real pain will be felt in categories that depend heavily on imports—like fresh vegetables in winter, where 60% come from Mexico. A 25% tariff there isn’t just a minor bump; it’s a full-on price surge that households will feel every time they go shopping.
Then there’s the domino effect. Mexico and Canada aren’t just sources of imports; they are the United States’ largest trading partners. Nearly 30% of all U.S. imports come from these two countries. Hit them with tariffs, and they’re going to hit back. That’s how trade wars work. The last time the U.S. got into a tariff battle, farmers in the Midwest found themselves with stockpiles of soybeans and no buyers, while manufacturers saw supply chains thrown into chaos. This isn’t theoretical—it’s history, repeating itself.
Consider the auto industry. Car manufacturing today is a tightly integrated process, with parts flowing back and forth across borders before a finished vehicle rolls off the assembly line. A 25% tariff on those parts doesn’t mean Mexico and Canada pay more—it means car prices in America go up, factories slow down, and workers face layoffs. A policy meant to protect American jobs could end up putting thousands of them at risk.
